subject: RE: [junit] Announce: JDepend 1.4

messageBody:
If that's all, it's pretty trivial (i.e. no code required). You just need a
file that describes the tools menu item names and the class to launch, like
the one that JUnit uses in <va java install
dir>\ide\tools\test-ui\default.ini:

----
Name=JUnit
Version=3.7
Menu-Items=\
JUnit,junit.ui.TestRunner, ;\
JUnit,junit.ui.TestRunner,-c
Quick-Start-Items=JUnit,junit.ui.TestRunner
----

This installs a menu item in the main browser tools dropdown, and a menu
item in the class browser tools popup.
The -c means to pass the name of the class as an argument to the
main(String[]) for the given class. Other options are -p for package, -P for
project, etc.

Mike

> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > JDepend 1.4, the freely-available Java package dependency
> > > > > analyzer, has
> > > > > been released. Of particular interest to JUnit users is
> > > > > the ability to
> > > > > write tests that automatically check metrics tolerances,
> > > > > existence of
> > > > > package dependency cycles, and package dependency
> > constraints.
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > New Features:
> > > > >
> > > > > - Added package dependency constraints to support writing
> > > > > tests that
> > > > > fail if any package dependency other than those declared in
> > the
> > > > > dependency constraints are detected. Refer to the
> > > > > documentation or the
> > > > > jdepend.framework.ConstraintTest class for complete
> > examples.
> > > > >
> > > > > For example, the following test case method will fail
> > > > > if the analyzed
> > > > > packages contain any dependencies other than those declared
> > in
> > > > the
> > > > > dependency constraint:
> > > > >
> > > > > public void testDependencyConstraint() {
> > > > >
> > > > > JavaPackage ejb = new JavaPackage("com.xyz.ejb");
> > > > > JavaPackage web = new JavaPackage("com.xyz.web");
> > > > > JavaPackage util = new JavaPackage("com.xyz.util");
> > > > >
> > > > > ejb.dependsUpon(util);
> > > > > web.dependsUpon(util);
> > > > >
> > > > > DependencyConstraint constraint = new
> > > > > DependencyConstraint();
> > > > > constraint.addPackage(ejb);
> > > > > constraint.addPackage(web);
> > > > > constraint.addPackage(util);
> > > > >
> > > > > _jdepend.analyze();
> > > > >
> > > > > assert(_jdepend.dependencyMatch(constraint));
> > > > > }
> > > > >
> > > > > - Added the jdepend.xmlui.JDepend class to generate
> > > > > package metrics,
> > > > > dependencies, and cycles in an XML format for easier
> > > > > integration with
> > > > > other tools.
> > > > >
> > > > > Example usage:
> > > > > java jdepend.xmlui.JDepend -file report.xml
> > > > /myproject/src
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > The JDepend documentation is available at
> > > > >
> > > > > http://www.clarkware.com/software/JDepend.html
> > > > >
> > > > > JDepend 1.4 can be downloaded directly from
> > > > >
> > > > > http://www.clarkware.com/software/jdepend1.4.zip
> > > > >
> > > > >
> > > > > Any feedback you may have is most welcome and appreciated.
> > > > >
> > > > > Thanks and enjoy!
